Quo Vadis, Sharpness? Understanding Progressive Sharpening and Edge of Stability

Study - Machine Learning

Analysis and further investigation on the behavior of progressive sharpness and edge of stability in gradient descent when training neural networks.

Paper

Process

In this study, research on the behavior of sharpness and edge of stability was conducted on gradient descent.

Gradient descent is a key algorithm in the optimization of machine learning models and neural networks. Traditionally, optimization theory links the optimal learning rate η to the largest eigenvalue in the Hessian matrix of the weights, also know as the sharpness.

Recent work by [Cohen et al. 2021] reveals two phenomena: Progressive Sharpening, where sharpness increases monotonically until reaching the instability cutoff 2/η, and Edge of Stability, where sharpness stabilizes at 2/η while training loss continues to decrease. However, the mechanisms behind these two new behaviors is still not well understood.

We conducted an empirical study on further unexplored aspects of these behaviors:

  • Development and validation of a hypothesis behind progressive sharpening
  • Effects of dataset complexity
  • Different loss functions
  • Model architecture and under/over-parameterization
  • Generalization capacity
  • Evolution of each weight during training and instability

Our hypothesis suggests a correlation between changes in the weights and sharpness. Our experiments consistently show weights following the trajectory of the sharpness, persisting across various experiments and parameters. Notably, as sharpness oscillates post-Edge of Stability, we observe corresponding oscillations in the weights.
